Sugarless Wheat Sponge Cake

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to a healthier twist on a classic dessert with our Sugarless Wheat Sponge Cake recipe! This delightful cake is not only light and fluffy but also made with wholesome ingredients that cater to your health-conscious lifestyle. By substituting traditional sugar with unsweetened applesauce, this recipe allows you to enjoy a sweet treat without the guilt. Perfect for afternoon tea or as a wholesome dessert, this cake is crafted with whole wheat flour, making it a great source of fiber. Whether you're looking to impress guests or simply satisfy your sweet tooth, our Sugarless Wheat Sponge Cake is a delicious option that prioritizes your well-being while still delivering on taste. Get ready to bake a cake that everyone can enjoy, regardless of dietary restrictions!

Ingredients

whole wheat flour

Whole wheat flour adds a nutty flavor and denser texture to the cake. If you want a lighter texture, consider using half whole wheat and half all-purpose flour. Also, make sure to sift the flour before measuring to avoid compacting it.

baking powder

Ensure your baking powder is fresh for optimal leavening. If you don't have baking powder, you can substitute with 1 tsp of baking soda and 1/2 tsp of cream of tartar.

baking soda

Baking soda requires an acid to activate it, so the combination with the applesauce is perfect. If you don’t have baking soda, you can increase the baking powder to 1 1/2 tsp instead, but the cake may be denser.

unsweetened applesauce

Applesauce acts as a natural sweetener and moisture provider. If you need a substitute, you can use mashed bananas or pureed pumpkin, but these may alter the flavor slightly.

eggs

Eggs provide structure and moisture. If you're looking for an egg substitute, consider using 1/4 cup of unsweetened applesauce or 1/4 cup of yogurt for each egg.

vanilla extract

Vanilla extract enhances the overall flavor of the cake. For a different flavor profile, you can substitute with almond extract or even a bit of citrus zest.

salt

Salt enhances all flavors in baked goods, so don’t skip it. If you're watching your sodium intake, you can reduce it to a pinch.

milk (or almond milk)

Milk adds moisture to the cake. If you want a dairy-free option, almond milk works great. You can also use oat milk or soy milk as alternatives.

olive oil (or melted coconut oil)

Olive oil contributes healthy fats and moisture. If you prefer a different flavor, melted coconut oil or even vegetable oil can be used, but coconut oil will add a subtle coconut flavor.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Preheat Your Oven

    Set your oven to 350°F (175°C) to ensure it's hot enough when you place your cake inside. This is crucial for even baking.

  • Step 2: Prepare the Cake Pan

    Grease and flour an 8-inch round cake pan. This prevents the cake from sticking. Alternatively, you can line the bottom with parchment paper for easier removal.

  • Step 3: Mix Dry Ingredients

    In a bowl, combine 1 cup of whole wheat flour, 1 tsp of baking powder, 1/2 tsp of baking soda, and 1/4 tsp of salt. Whisk together until evenly mixed. This step helps distribute the leavening agents evenly throughout the flour.

  • Step 4: Combine Wet Ingredients

    In another bowl, whisk together 3 large eggs, 1/2 cup of unsweetened applesauce, 1/4 cup of olive oil (or melted coconut oil), 1/4 cup of milk (or almond milk), and 1 tsp of vanilla extract until smooth. Ensure there are no lumps.

  • Step 5: Combine Wet and Dry Ingredients

    Gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet mixture, stirring gently until just combined. Be careful not to overmix, as this can make the cake dense.

  • Step 6: Pour Batter into Pan

    Carefully pour the batter into the prepared cake pan, using a spatula to spread it evenly.

  • Step 7: Bake the Cake

    Place the cake in the preheated oven and bake for 25 minutes. To check for doneness, insert a toothpick into the center; it should come out clean. If not, bake for a few more minutes.

  • Step 8: Cool the Cake

    Once baked, allow the cake to cool in the pan for 10 minutes. Then, transfer it to a wire rack to cool completely. This helps prevent sogginess on the bottom.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is the purpose of using whole wheat flour instead of all-purpose flour?

Whole wheat flour is more nutritious than all-purpose flour, providing more fiber and nutrients. It can also add a nuttier flavor and denser texture to your cake. For beginners, it’s a great way to make your baking healthier!

How do I know when my cake is done baking?

A cake is done when a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean or with a few moist crumbs. For this cake, check it after 25 minutes, but keep an eye on it, as oven temperatures can vary.

Can I substitute the applesauce for something else?

Yes, you can replace unsweetened applesauce with mashed bananas, yogurt, or even pureed pumpkin. These alternatives will also keep your cake moist while adding different flavors.

What if I don't have vanilla extract?

If you don’t have vanilla extract, you can omit it or substitute with almond extract or another flavoring like lemon zest or orange zest for a different twist!

How do I properly grease and flour my cake pan?

To grease a pan, use a little oil or butter and spread it evenly across the bottom and sides. Then, sprinkle flour inside the pan, tapping it around to coat the greased areas. This helps the cake to not stick after baking.

What can I do if my batter is too thick?

If your batter seems too thick, you can add a little more milk (or almond milk) a tablespoon at a time until you reach a pourable consistency. Just be careful not to add too much!

Are there any tips for cleaning up after baking?

To make cleanup easier, gather all your ingredients and tools before you start baking. Use parchment paper for your cake pan, and soak any mixing bowls or utensils in warm soapy water right after use to avoid hard-to-clean batter.

How can I store leftover cake?

Store leftover cake in an airtight container at room temperature for 2-3 days or in the refrigerator for up to a week. You can also freeze it for longer storage; just ensure it’s wrapped tightly to prevent freezer burn.

What should I do if my cake doesn’t rise?

If your cake doesn’t rise, it could be due to expired baking powder or baking soda, or not properly mixing the ingredients. Always check the freshness of your leavening agents and ensure you mix until just combined, as over-mixing can deflate the batter.

Is it safe to use olive oil in baking?

Absolutely! Olive oil is a healthy fat that works well in baking. It may impart a subtle flavor, but it’s generally well-balanced in recipes like this cake.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This cake is naturally low in sugar, making it suitable for those looking to reduce their sugar intake. For gluten-free options, substitute whole wheat flour with a 1:1 gluten-free flour blend. To make it dairy-free, use almond milk as suggested in the ingredients. Additionally, for a vegan version, replace eggs with flaxseed meal (1 tablespoon flaxseed meal + 2.5 tablespoons water per egg) and ensure that the yogurt or cream used for layering is also dairy-free.

Pairings

For a delightful pairing, enjoy the Sugarless Wheat Sponge Cake with fresh sliced strawberries or raspberries. The natural sweetness and acidity of the berries complement the cake's flavor beautifully. A dollop of unsweetened whipped cream or a drizzle of honey (or agave syrup for a vegan option) can enhance the dessert experience. For beverages, consider serving with herbal tea, such as chamomile or mint, or a light sparkling water with a hint of lemon for a refreshing contrast.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the Sugarless Wheat Sponge Cake at room temperature for the best texture. To elevate the presentation, dust the top lightly with cocoa powder or cinnamon before serving. You can also layer the cake with a light yogurt or whipped cream in between slices for extra creaminess. For a more festive touch, add a sprinkle of chopped nuts (like almonds or walnuts) or a few edible flowers on top to enhance visual appeal and add a crunchy texture.

#

Sugarless Wheat Sponge Cake

40 min
$5
120 kcal
Difficulty: 30%
Servings: 8

Allergens:

Eggs

Dietary Tags:

Low SugarWhole GrainVegetarian

Cuisine:

American

Course:

Dessert

Tags:

CakeDessertHealthy

Description

A light and fluffy cake sweetened naturally, perfect for a healthier dessert option!

Ingredients

  • whole wheat flour: 1 cup
  • baking powder: 1 tsp
  • baking soda: 1/2 tsp
  • unsweetened applesauce: 1/2 cup
  • eggs: 3 large
  • vanilla extract: 1 tsp
  • salt: 1/4 tsp
  • milk (or almond milk): 1/4 cup
  • olive oil (or melted coconut oil): 1/4 cup

Date Created:

11/16/2024
